member.name: F:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.PointerID
member.summary: A unique identifier for the pointer causing the event. This identifier MUST be unique from all other active pointers in the top-level browsing context (as defined by [HTML5]) at the time. A user agent MAY recycle previously retired values for pointerId from previous active pointers, if necessary.

members.member:
If True this device is the "master" pointer
Docs: https://w3c.github.io/pointerevents/#the-primary-pointer

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.Buttons
member.summary: All of the currently pressed buttons for this pointer device

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.Width
member.summary: The width (magnitude on the X axis), in CSS pixels (see [CSS21]), of the contact geometry of the pointer. This value MAY be updated on each event for a given pointer. For inputs that typically lack contact geometry (such as a traditional mouse), and in cases where the actual geometry of the input is not detected by the hardware, this MUST return a default value of 1.

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.Height
member.summary: The height (magnitude on the Y axis), in CSS pixels (see [CSS21]), of the contact geometry of the pointer. This value MAY be updated on each event for a given pointer. For inputs that typically lack contact geometry (such as a traditional mouse), and in cases where the actual geometry of the input is not detected by the hardware, this MUST return a default value of 1.

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.Pressure
member.summary: The normalized pressure of the pointer input in the range of [0,1], where 0 and 1 represent the minimum and maximum pressure the hardware is capable of detecting, respectively. For hardware and platforms that do not support pressure, the value MUST be 0.5 when in the active buttons state and 0 otherwise. Note: all pointerup events will have pressure 0.

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.TangentalPressure
member.summary: The normalized tangential pressure (also known as barrel pressure), typically set by an additional control (e.g. a finger wheel on an airbrush stylus), of the pointer input in the range of [-1,1], where 0 is the neutral position of the control. Note that some hardware may only support positive values in the range of [0,1]. For hardware and platforms that do not support tangential pressure, the value MUST be 0.

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.TiltX
member.summary: The plane angle (in degrees, in the range of [-90,90]) between the Y-Z plane and the plane containing both the transducer (e.g. pen stylus) axis and the Y axis. A positive tiltX is to the right. tiltX can be used along with tiltY to represent the tilt away from the normal of a transducer with the digitizer. For hardware and platforms that do not report tilt, the value MUST be 0.

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.TiltY
member.summary: The plane angle (in degrees, in the range of [-90,90]) between the X-Z plane and the plane containing both the transducer (e.g. pen stylus) axis and the X axis. A positive tiltY is towards the user. tiltY can be used along with tiltX to represent the tilt away from the normal of a transducer with the digitizer. For hardware and platforms that do not report tilt, the value MUST be 0.

member.name: P:CssUI.Devices.PointerDevice.Twist
member.summary: The clockwise rotation (in degrees, in the range of [0,359]) of a transducer (e.g. pen stylus) around its own major axis. For hardware and platforms that do not report twist, the value MUST be 0.

member.name: T:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker
member.summary: A more generic tree walker based on the one from the DOM web standards

member.name: M:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker.ParentNode
member.summary: Returns the next node in a sequence containing all nodes in the parent chain(in reverse tree order)

member.name: M:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker.FirstChild
member.summary: Returns the next node in a sequence containing all first-child descendant nodes and the siblings of the bottom-most node(in tree order)

member.name: M:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker.LastChild
member.summary: Returns the next node in a sequence containing all descendant nodes (in reverse tree order)

member.name: M:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker.NextSibling
member.summary: Returns the next node in a sequence containing all sibling nodes of the root and their children (in tree order)

member.name: M:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker.PreviousSibling
member.summary: Returns the next node in a sequence containing all sibling nodes of the root and their children (in reverse tree order)

member.name: M:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker.PreviousNode
member.summary: Returns the next node in a sequence containing all ancestor nodes of the root (in reverse tree order)

member.name: M:CssUI.NodeTree.NodeTreeWalker.NextNode
member.summary:
Returns the next node in a sequence containing the complete tree of all descendant nodes from the root (in tree order)
Basically itterates through the first child of every descendent node until it hits one it doesnt accept, then starts returning the rest of the nodes within the roots tree in order from left-right and from bottom-top

member.name: M:CssUI.Platform.Windows.Win32.User32.GetDesktopWindow
member.summary: Returns a handle to the desktop window

member.name: M:CssUI.Platform.Windows.Win32.User32.GetDoubleClickTime
member.summary: Retrieves the current double-click time for the mouse. A double-click is a series of two clicks of the mouse button, the second occurring within a specified time after the first. The double-click time is the maximum number of milliseconds that may occur between the first and second click of a double-click. The maximum double-click time is 5000 milliseconds.

member.name: M:CssUI.Platform.Windows.Win32.User32.MonitorFromWindow(System.IntPtr,CssUI.Platform.Windows.Win32.MONITOR_FLAG)
member.summary:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd145064(v=vs.85).aspx
Retrieves a handle to the display monitor that has the largest area of intersection with the bounding rectangle of a specified window.

member.name: T:CssUI.AtomicName`1
member.summary:
Implements an efficient way of referring to common string names without constantly performing costly string comparisons. Allows identifying common names via an enum which maps to a lookup table This is used for things like DOM element attributes, and CSS property names.
AtomicNames can effectively be thought of as self indexing strings, Maps and lists of AtomicNames cease being indexed by strings and instead are effectively indexed by their self assigned integer values

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssAnonymousBox
member.summary:
An anonymous box is a box that is not associated with any element. Anonymous boxes are generated in certain circumstances to fix up the box tree when it requires a particular nested structure that is not provided by the boxes generated from the element tree.
(Holds children and its style data is linked to its parent nodes but can have style properties individually overriden)

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssBox
member.summary: Represents a box-model object which holds other box-model objects as children

member.summary: Adds a flag to the dirty bit

member.summary: Removes a flag for the dirty bit

member.name: P:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssBox.IsBlockContainer
member.summary: A block container either contains only inline-level boxes participating in an inline formatting context, or contains only block-level boxes participating in a block formatting context (possibly generating anonymous block boxes to ensure this constraint, as defined in CSS29.2.1.1).

member.name: P:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssBox.IsBlockLevel
member.summary: Content that participates in block layout. Specifically, block-level boxes have an Outer display type of 'Block'

member.name: P:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssBox.IsInlineLevel
member.summary: Content that participates in inline layout. Specifically, inline-level boxes and text runs.

member.name: P:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssBox.IsBlockBox
member.summary:
A block-level box that is also a block container.
Note: Not all block container boxes are block-level boxes: non-replaced inline blocks and non-replaced table cells, for example.

member.name: P:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssBox.IsInlineBox
member.summary: A non-replaced inline-level box whose inner display type is flow. The contents of an inline box participate in the same inline formatting context as the inline box itself.

member.name: P:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssBox.IsAtomicInline
member.summary: An inline-level box that is replaced (such as an image) or that establishes a new formatting context (such as an inline-block or inline-table) and cannot split across lines (as inline boxes and ruby containers can). Any inline-level box whose inner display type is not flow establishes a new formatting context of the specified inner display type.

member.summary: The smallest size a box could take that doesnt lead to overflow that could be avoided by choosing a larger size. (See 4 Intrinsic Size Determination.)

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssPrincipalBox.Min_Content_Inline
member.summary: The narrowest inline size a box could take that doesnt lead to inline-dimension overflow that could be avoided by choosing a larger inline size. Roughly, the inline size that would fit around its contents if all soft wrap opportunities within the box were taken.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssPrincipalBox.Min_Content_Block
member.summary: In general, and definitely for block-level and inline-level boxes, this is equivalent to the max-content block size.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssPrincipalBox.Max_Content
member.summary: A boxs ideal size in a given axis when given infinite available space. Usually this is the smallest size the box could take in that axis while still fitting around its contents, i.e. minimizing unfilled space while avoiding overflow.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssPrincipalBox.Max_Content_Inline
member.summary: The boxs ideal size in the inline axis. Usually the narrowest inline size it could take while fitting around its contents if none of the soft wrap opportunities within the box were taken. (See 4 Intrinsic Size Determination.)

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.BoxTree.CssPrincipalBox.Max_Content_Block
member.summary: The boxs ideal size in the block axis. Usually the block size of the content after layout.

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.Enums.ECssBoxType
member.summary: Specifies an area-type for a CSS box

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType
member.summary: the inner display type, which defines (if it is a non-replaced element) the kind of formatting context it generates, dictating how its descendant boxes are laid out. (The inner display of a replaced element is outside the scope of CSS.)

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType.None
member.summary: This element does not generate boxes.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType.Flow
member.summary: The element lays out its contents using flow layout (block-and-inline layout). If its outer display type is inline or run-in, and it is participating in a block or inline formatting context, then it generates an inline box. Otherwise it generates a block container box. Depending on the value of other properties (such as position, float, or overflow) and whether it is itself participating in a block or inline formatting context, it either establishes a new block formatting context for its contents or integrates its contents into its parent formatting context.See CSS2.1 Chapter 9. [CSS2] A block container that establishes a new block formatting context is considered to have a used inner display type of flow-root.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType.Flow_Root
member.summary: The element generates a block container box, and lays out its contents using flow layout. It always establishes a new block formatting context for its contents.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType.Table
member.summary: The element generates a principal table wrapper box that establishes a block formatting context, and which contains an additionally-generated table grid box that establishes a table formatting context.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType.Flex
member.summary: The element generates a principal flex container box and establishes a flex formatting context.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType.Grid
member.summary: The element generates a principal grid container box, and establishes a grid formatting context.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EInnerDisplayType.Ruby
member.summary: The element generates a ruby container box and establishes a ruby formatting context in addition to integrating its base-level contents into its parent formatting context (if it is inline) or generating a wrapper box of the appropriate outer display type (if it is not).

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EOuterDisplayType
member.summary: Defines the *-level of a box, whether it is block-level, inline-level, or other. Dictates how the principal box itself participates in flow layout.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EOuterDisplayType.None
member.summary: This element does not generate boxes.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EOuterDisplayType.Block
member.summary: Block-level elements those elements of the source document that are formatted visually as blocks (e.g., paragraphs) are elements which generate a block-level principal box. Values of the 'display' property that make an element block-level include: 'block', 'list-item', and 'table'. Block-level boxes are boxes that participate in a block formatting context.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EOuterDisplayType.Inline
member.summary: The element generates a box that is inline-level when placed in flow layout.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EOuterDisplayType.Run_In
member.summary: The element generates an run-in box, which is a type of inline-level box with special behavior that attempts to merge it into a subsequent block container. See 3 Run-In Layout for details.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Enums.EPropertyStage.Assigned

member.summary: A value that has been interpreted through inheritence or defaulting.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Internal.ESelectorCombinator.Descendant
member.summary: '>>' or ' ' Descendant combinators express such a relationship. A descendant combinator is whitespace that separates two sequences of simple selectors. A selector of the form "A B" represents an element B that is an arbitrary descendant of some ancestor element A.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Internal.ESelectorCombinator.Child
member.summary: '>' A child combinator describes a childhood relationship between two elements. A child combinator is made of the "greater-than sign" (U+003E, >) character and separates two sequences of simple selectors.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Internal.ESelectorCombinator.Sibling_Adjacent
member.summary: '+' The next-sibling combinator is made of the "plus sign" (U+002B, +) character that separates two sequences of simple selectors. The elements represented by the two sequences share the same parent in the document tree and the element represented by the first sequence immediately precedes the element represented by the second one.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Internal.ESelectorCombinator.Sibling_Subsequent
member.summary: '~' The subsequent-sibling combinator is made of the "tilde" (U+007E, ~) character that separates two sequences of simple selectors. The elements represented by the two sequences share the same parent in the document tree and the element represented by the first sequence precedes (not necessarily immediately) the element represented by the second one.

member.summary: Combinators specify how a media query determines if it's set of features cause it to match a given document

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaCombinator.OR
member.summary: Instantly returns true for a match

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaCombinator.NOT
member.summary: Negates the comparison result for a match

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureContext
member.summary: Specifies how a should evaluate its components

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Width
member.summary: The width media feature describes the width of the targeted display area of the output device. For continuous media, this is the width of the viewport (as described by CSS2, section 9.1.1 [CSS21]) including the size of a rendered scroll bar (if any). For paged media, this is the width of the page box (as described by CSS2, section 13.2 [CSS21]).

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Height
member.summary: The height media feature describes the height of the targeted display area of the output device. For continuous media, this is the height of the viewport including the size of a rendered scroll bar (if any). For paged media, this is the height of the page box.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.AspectRatio
member.summary: The aspect-ratio media feature is defined as the ratio of the value of the width media feature to the value of the height media feature.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Orientation
member.summary: portrait: The orientation media feature is portrait when the value of the height media feature is greater than or equal to the value of the width media feature. landscape: Otherwise orientation is landscape.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Resolution
member.summary: The resolution media feature describes the resolution of the output device, i.e. the density of the pixels, taking into account the page zoom but assuming a pinch zoom of 1.0.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Scan
member.summary: The scan media feature describes the scanning process of some output devices.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Grid
member.summary: The grid media feature is used to query whether the output device is grid or bitmap. If the output device is grid-based (e.g., a tty terminal, or a phone display with only one fixed font), the value will be 1. Otherwise, the value will be 0.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Update
member.summary: The update media feature is used to query the ability of the output device to modify the apearance of content once it has been rendered.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.OverflowBlock
member.summary: The overflow-block media feature describes the behavior of the device when content overflows the initial containing block in the block axis.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.OverflowInline
member.summary: The overflow-inline media feature describes the behavior of the device when content overflows the initial containing block in the inline axis.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Color
member.summary: The color media feature describes the number of bits per color component of the output device. If the device is not a color device, the value is zero.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.ColorIndex
member.summary: The color-index media feature describes the number of entries in the color lookup table of the output device. If the device does not use a color lookup table, the value is zero.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.Monochrome
member.summary: The monochrome media feature describes the number of bits per pixel in a monochrome frame buffer. If the device is not a monochrome device, the output device value will be 0.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureName.ColorGamut
member.summary: The color-gamut media feature describes the approximate range of colors that are supported by the UA and output device. That is, if the UA receives content with colors in the specified space it can cause the output device to render the appropriate color, or something appropriately close enough.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureType.Discreet
member.summary: Feature is a single value

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaFeatureType.Range
member.summary: Feature is a value range

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOperator
member.summary: Describes the comparison logic for media a feature

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOrientation.Portrait
member.summary: The orientation media feature is portrait when the value of the height media feature is greater than or equal to the value of the width media feature.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOrientation.Landscape
member.summary: The orientation media feature is portrait when the value of the width media feature is greater than or equal to the value of the height media feature.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOverflowBlock.None
member.summary: There is no affordance for overflow in the block axis; any overflowing content is simply not displayed. Examples: billboards

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOverflowBlock.Scroll
member.summary: Overflowing content in the block axis is exposed by allowing users to scroll to it. Examples: computer screens

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOverflowBlock.Optional_Paged
member.summary: Overflowing content in the block axis is exposed by allowing users to scroll to it, but page breaks can be manually triggered (such as via break-inside, etc) to cause the following content to display on the following page. Examples: slideshows

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOverflowBlock.Paged
member.summary: Content is broken up into discrete pages; content that overflows one page in the block axis is displayed on the following page. Examples: printers, ebook readers

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOverflowInline.None
member.summary: There is no affordance for overflow in the block axis; any overflowing content is simply not displayed. Examples: billboards

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaOverflowInline.Scroll
member.summary: Overflowing content in the block axis is exposed by allowing users to scroll to it. Examples: computer screens

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaQueryModifier.Not
member.summary: Negates the media query result

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaQueryModifier.Only
member.summary: The only keyword has no effect on the media querys result, but will cause the media query to be parsed by legacy user agents as specifying the unknown media type only, and thus be ignored.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaScan.Interlace
member.summary: CRT and some types of plasma TV screens used interlaced rendering, where video frames alternated between specifying only the even lines on the screen and only the odd lines, exploiting various automatic mental image-correction abilities to produce smooth motion. This allowed them to simulate a higher FPS broadcast at half the bandwidth cost.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaScan.Progressive
member.summary: A screen using progressive rendering displays each screen fully, and needs no special treatment. Most modern screens, and all computer screens, use progressive rendering.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaType.All
member.summary: Matches all devices

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaType.Print
member.summary: Matches printers, and devices intended to reproduce a printed display, such as a web browser showing a document in Print Preview.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaType.Screen
member.summary: Matches all devices that arent matched by print or speech.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaType.Speech
member.summary: Matches devices that similar devices that read out a page.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaUpdate.None
member.summary: Once it has been rendered, the layout can no longer be updated. Example: documents printed on paper.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaUpdate.Slow
member.summary: The layout may change dynamically according to the usual rules of CSS, but the output device is not able to render or display changes quickly enough for them to be perceived as a smooth animation. Example: E-ink screens or severely under-powered devices.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.Media.EMediaUpdate.Fast
member.summary: The layout may change dynamically according to the usual rules of CSS, and the output device is not unusually constrained in speed, so regularly-updating things like CSS Animations can be used. Example: computer screens.

member.summary: Creates a new 'boolean' type media feature

member.summary: Creates a new 'range' type media feature

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.EBorderStyle
member.summary: Defines all the possible border styles

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBorderStyle.None
member.summary: No border, Color and width are ignored.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBorderStyle.Hidden
member.summary: Same as 'None' but with different conflict resolution for border-collapsed tables

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBoxPositioning.Static
member.summary: Element is normal, positioned via the normal layout logic

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBoxPositioning.Relative
member.summary: The box's position is calculated according to the normal flow (this is called the position in normal flow). Then the box is offset relative to its normal position. When a box B is relatively positioned, the position of the following box is calculated as though B were not offset. The effect of 'position:relative' on table-row-group, table-header-group, table-footer-group, table-row, table-column-group, table-column, table-cell, and table-caption elements is undefined.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBoxPositioning.Absolute
member.summary: The box's position (and possibly size) is specified with the 'top', 'right', 'bottom', and 'left' properties. These properties specify offsets with respect to the box's containing block. Absolutely positioned boxes are taken out of the normal flow. This means they have no impact on the layout of later siblings.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBoxPositioning.Fixed
member.summary: The box's position is calculated according to the 'absolute' model, but in addition, the box is fixed with respect to some reference. IE: the viewport.

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.EBoxSizingMode
member.summary: Describes all of the CSS box sizing modes used by the 'box-sizing' property

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBoxSizingMode.ContentBox
member.summary: Width/Height describe the size of the content area, not including the padding, border, or margins

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EBoxSizingMode.BorderBox
member.summary: Width/Height describe the border area, including the content size, padding, and border size but not the margins

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EDisplayMode.NONE
member.summary: This value causes an element to generate no boxes (i.e., the element has no effect on layout). Descendant elements do not generate any boxes either; this behavior cannot be overridden by setting the display property on the descendants.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EDisplayMode.INLINE
member.summary: Element takes up only as much space as it needs, inline elements cannot specify an explicit width or height, their dimensions are completely determined by their content.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EDisplayMode.BLOCK
member.summary: Element takes up an entire line by itself

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EFontStyle.Normal
member.summary: selects a face that is classified as a normal face, one that is neither italic or obliqued

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EFontStyle.Italic
member.summary: selects a font that is labeled as an italic face, or an oblique face if one is not

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EFontStyle.Oblique
member.summary: selects a font that is labeled as an oblique face, or an italic face if one is not

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EFontWeight.Lighter
member.summary: Specifies a lighter weight than the inherited value.

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.EGenericFontFamily
member.summary: Provides values to reference the CSS defined generic font familys

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.EObjectFit
member.summary:
All the different methods for applying size constraints to a UI element
"The object-fit property specifies how the contents of a replaced element should be fitted to the box established by its used height and width."

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EObjectFit.Fill
member.summary: The replaced content is sized to fill the element's content box: the object's concrete object size is the element's used width and height.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EObjectFit.Contain
member.summary: The replaced content is sized to maintain its aspect ratio while fitting within the element's content box: its concrete object size is resolved as a contain constraint against the element's used width and height.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EObjectFit.Cover
member.summary: The replaced content is sized to maintain its aspect ratio while filling the element's entire content box: its concrete object size is resolved as a cover constraint against the element's used width and height.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EObjectFit.None
member.summary: The replaced content is not resized to fit inside the element's content box: determine the object's concrete object size using the default sizing algorithm with no specified size, and a default object size equal to the replaced element's used width and height.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EObjectFit.Scale_Down
member.summary: Size the content as if none or contain were specified, whichever would result in a smaller concrete object size.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EOverflowMode.Visible
member.summary: There is no special handling of overflow, that is, it may be rendered outside the box. The box is not a scroll container.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EOverflowMode.Hidden
member.summary: This value indicates that the boxs content is clipped to its padding box and that no scrolling user interface should be provided by the UA to view the content outside the clipping region. However, the content may still be scrolled programatically, for example using the mechanisms defined in [CSSOM-VIEW], and the box is therefore still a scroll container.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EOverflowMode.Clip
member.summary: Like hidden, this value indicates that the boxs content is clipped to its padding box and that no scrolling user interface should be provided by the UA to view the content outside the clipping region. In addition, unlike overflow: hidden which still allows programmatic scrolling, overflow: clip forbids scrolling entirely, through any mechanism, and therefore the box is not a scroll container.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EOverflowMode.Scroll
member.summary: This value indicates that the content is clipped to the padding box, but can be scrolled into view (and therefore the box is a scroll container). Furthermore, if the user agent uses a scrolling mechanism that is visible on the screen (such as a scroll bar or a panner), that mechanism should be displayed whether or not any of its content is clipped. This avoids any problem with scrollbars appearing and disappearing in a dynamic environment. When this value is specified and the target medium is print, overflowing content may be printed.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EOverflowMode.Auto
member.summary: This value indicates that the boxs content is clipped to the padding box, but can be scrolled into view (and therefore the box is a scroll container). However, if the user agent uses a scrolling mechanism that is visible on the screen (such as a scroll bar or a panner), that mechanism should only be displayed if there is overflow.

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.EPositioningScheme
member.summary: Defines all of the different positioning 'scheme' types for elements

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EPositioningScheme.Normal
member.summary: Object is positioned according to normal flow logic

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EPositioningScheme.Float
member.summary: Object is laid out like in normal flow but then moved as far left or right as possible

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EPositioningScheme.Absolute
member.summary: Object is not positioned according to normal flow, it defines it's own position relative to a block other than its logical containing block

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EScrollBehavior.Auto
member.summary: The scrolling box is scrolled in an instant fashion.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.EScrollBehavior.Smooth
member.summary: The scrolling box is scrolled in a smooth fashion using a user-agent-defined timing function over a user-agent-defined period of time.

member.name: T:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign
member.summary: A block of text is a stack of line boxes. This property specifies how the inline-level boxes within each line box align with respect to the start and end sides of the line box. Alignment is not with respect to the viewport or containing block.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.Start
member.summary: Inline-level content is aligned to the start edge of the line box.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.End
member.summary: Inline-level content is aligned to the end edge of the line box.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.Left
member.summary: Inline-level content is aligned to the line left edge of the line box. (In vertical writing modes, this will be either the physical top or bottom, depending on text-orientation.) [CSS3-WRITING-MODES]

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.Right
member.summary: Inline-level content is aligned to the line right edge of the line box. (In vertical writing modes, this will be either the physical top or bottom, depending on text-orientation.) [CSS3-WRITING-MODES]

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.Center
member.summary: Inline-level content is centered within the line box.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.Justify
member.summary: Text is justified according to the method specified by the text-justify property, in order to exactly fill the line box.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.MatchParent
member.summary: This value behaves the same as inherit (computes to its parent's computed value) except that an inherited start or end keyword is interpreted against its parent's direction value and results in a computed value of either left or right.

member.name: F:CssUI.CSS.ETextAlign.StartEnd
member.summary: Specifies start alignment of the first line and any line immediately after a forced line break; and end alignment of any remaining lines.

members.member: Docs: https://www.w3.org/TR/css-writing-modes-4/#logical-to-physical

member.name: T:CssUI.DOM.Internal.BrowsingContext
member.summary:
A browsing context is like an abstract way for a document to interact with the environment its being presented from. Because a document could be just in a normal window or possibly embedded within a control element in which case it isnt directly contained in a window but still is owned by one, so it needs to reference the window object at its' root.
"A browsing context is an environment in which Document objects are presented to the user."

The top layer is an ordered set of elements, rendered in the order they appear in the set. The last element in the set is rendered last, and thus appears on top.
Docs: https://fullscreen.spec.whatwg.org/#top-layer

member.name: M:CssUI.DOM.Document.getElementsByTagNameNS(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: If namespace and localName are "*" returns a collection of all descendant elements. If only namespace is "*" returns a collection of all descendant elements whose local name is localName. If only localName is "*" returns a collection of all descendant elements whose namespace is namespace. Otherwise, returns a collection of all descendant elements whose namespace is namespace and local name is localName.

member.name: M:CssUI.DOM.Document.getElementsByClassName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a collection of the elements in the object on which the method was invoked (a document or an element) that have all the classes given by classNames. The classNames argument is interpreted as a space-separated list of classes.

member.name: M:CssUI.DOM.Document.createElement(System.String,CssUI.DOM.ElementCreationOptions)
member.summary: Returns an element with localName as local name (if document is an HTML document, localName gets lowercased). The elements namespace is the HTML namespace when document is an HTML document or documents content type is "application/xhtml+xml", and null otherwise. If localName does not match the Name production an "InvalidCharacterError" DOMException will be thrown. When supplied, optionss is can be used to create a customized built-in element.

member.name: M:CssUI.DOM.Document.createElementNS(System.String,System.String,CssUI.DOM.ElementCreationOptions)
member.summary: Returns an element with namespace namespace. Its namespace prefix will be everything before ":" (U+003E) in qualifiedName or null. Its local name will be everything after ":" (U+003E) in qualifiedName or qualifiedName. If localName does not match the Name production an "InvalidCharacterError" DOMException will be thrown. If one of the following conditions is true a "NamespaceError" DOMException will be thrown: localName does not match the QName production. Namespace prefix is not null and namespace is the empty string. Namespace prefix is "xml" and namespace is not the XML namespace. qualifiedName or namespace prefix is "xmlns" and namespace is not the XMLNS namespace. namespace is the XMLNS namespace and neither qualifiedName nor namespace prefix is "xmlns". When supplied, optionss is can be used to create a customized built-in element.

members.member:
The term focusable area is used to refer to regions of the interface that can become the target of keyboard input. Focusable areas can be elements, parts of elements, or other regions managed by the user agent.
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interaction.html#focused-area-of-the-document

member.name: M:CssUI.DOM.Document.hasFocus
member.summary: Returns true if key events are being routed through or to the document; otherwise, returns false. Roughly speaking, this corresponds to the document, or a document nested inside this one, being focused.

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.Nodes.Node.isInert
member.summary: A node (in particular elements and text nodes) can be marked as inert. When a node is inert, then the user agent must act as if the node was absent for the purposes of targeting user interaction events, may ignore the node for the purposes of text search user interfaces (commonly known as "find in page"), and may prevent the user from selecting text in that node. User agents should allow the user to override the restrictions on search and text selection, however.

member.name: P:CssUI.DOM.Text.is_expressly_inert
member.summary: A node (in particular elements and text nodes) can be marked as inert. When a node is inert, then the user agent must act as if the node was absent for the purposes of targeting user interaction events, may ignore the node for the purposes of text search user interfaces (commonly known as "find in page"), and may prevent the user from selecting text in that node. User agents should allow the user to override the restrictions on search and text selection, however.

member.name: T:CssUI.DOM.Enums.EAttributeType

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.Enums.EAttributeType.String
member.summary: Any string is valid

members.member:
A number of attributes are boolean attributes. The presence of a boolean attribute on an element represents the true value, and the absence of the attribute represents the false value. If the attribute is present, its value must either be the empty string or a value that is an ASCII case-insensitive match for the attribute's canonical name, with no leading or trailing whitespace.
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#boolean-attributes

Enumerated attributes may only be assigned a specific set of keywords with special meaning
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#keywords-and-enumerated-attributes

A string is a valid integer if it consists of one or more ASCII digits, optionally prefixed with a U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS character (-).
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#signed-integers

A string is a valid non-negative integer if it consists of one or more ASCII digits.
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#non-negative-integers

A string is a valid floating-point number if it consists of only an optional hypen(-), a series of digits, an optional period(.), followed by a series of digits
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#floating-point-numbers

A length is a floating point number greater than or equal to 0.0
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#percentages-and-dimensions

A percentage is a floating point number greater than or equal to 0.0 followed by a percent sign (%)
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#percentages-and-dimensions

A non-zero length is a floating point number greater than 0.0
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#non-zero-percentages-and-lengths

A non-zero percentage is a floating point number greater than 0.0 followed by a percent sign(%)
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#non-zero-percentages-and-lengths

A simple color consists of three 8-bit numbers in the range 0..255, representing the red, green, and blue components of the color respectively, in the sRGB color space. [SRGB]
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#colours

A time consists of a specific time with no time-zone information, consisting of an hour, a minute, a second, and a fraction of a second.
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#times

A date consists of a specific proleptic-Gregorian date with no time-zone information, consisting of a year, a month, and a day. [GREGORIAN]
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#dates

A duration consists of a number of seconds.
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#durations

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Image

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Audio
member.summary: An audio MIME type is any MIME type whose type is "audio" or whose essence is "application/ogg".

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Video
member.summary: An video MIME type is any MIME type whose type is "video"

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Font
member.summary:
A font MIME type is any MIME type whose type is "font", or whose essence is one of the following: [RFC8081]
application/font-cff, application/font-off, application/font-sfnt, application/font-ttf, application/font-woff, application/vnd.ms-fontobject, application/vnd.ms-opentype,

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Zip
member.summary:
A ZIP-based MIME type is any MIME type whose subtype ends in "+zip" or whose essence is one of the following:
application/zip

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Archive
member.summary:
An archive MIME type is any MIME type whose essence is one of the following:
application/x-rar-compressed, application/zip, application/x-gzip,

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.XML
member.summary: An XML MIME type is any MIME type whose subtype ends in "+xml" or whose essence is "text/xml" or "application/xml". [RFC7303]

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.HTML
member.summary: An HTML MIME type is any MIME type whose essence is "text/html".

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Scriptable
member.summary: A scriptable MIME type is an XML MIME type, HTML MIME type, or any MIME type whose essence is "application/pdf".

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.Javascript
member.summary:
A JavaScript MIME type is any MIME type whose essence is one of the following:
application/ecmascript, application/javascript, application/x-ecmascript, application/x-javascript, text/ecmascript, text/javascript, text/javascript1.0, text/javascript1.1, text/javascript1.2, text/javascript1.3, text/javascript1.4, text/javascript1.5, text/jscript, text/livescript, text/x-ecmascript, text/x-javascript,

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.EMimeGroup.JSON
member.summary: A JSON MIME type is any MIME type whose subtype ends in "+json" or whose essence is "application/json" or "text/json".

member.summary: Returns true or false depending on how event was initialized. True if event goes through its targets ancestors in reverse tree order, and false otherwise.

member.name: F:CssUI.DOM.Events.Event.cancelable
member.summary: Returns true or false depending on how event was initialized. Its return value does not always carry meaning, but true can indicate that part of the operation during which event was dispatched, can be canceled by invoking the preventDefault() method.

member.summary: Returns the object to which event is dispatched (its target).

member.name: P:CssUI.DOM.Events.Event.isTrusted

member.name: P:CssUI.DOM.Events.Event.timeStamp

member.name: P:CssUI.DOM.Events.Event.composed

member.name: M:CssUI.DOM.Events.Event.stopImmediatePropagation

member.name: M:CssUI.DOM.TreeWalker.nextNode
member.summary:
Returns the next node in a sequence containing the complete tree of all descendant nodes from the root (in tree order)
Basically itterates through the first child of every descendent node until it hits one it doesnt accept, then starts returning the rest of the nodes within the roots tree in order from left-right and from bottom-top

members.member:
The term focusable area is used to refer to regions of the interface that can become the target of keyboard input. Focusable areas can be elements, parts of elements, or other regions managed by the user agent.
Docs: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interaction.html#currently-focused-area-of-a-top-level-browsing-context

member.name: T:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase
member.summary: Provides an implementation of a basic render engine with a stack.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Begin
member.summary:
Prepares the engine to begin rendering a new frame.
Ensure that:
DepthTesting = OFF
Blending = ON

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.End
member.summary: Releases the engine when it is done rendering the current frame.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Reset
member.summary: Resets all states to their defaults

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Push
member.summary: Pushes a new copy of any stacking values onto their respective stacks, each UI element calls this at the start of it's rendering function EG: Blending color, clipping region, etc.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Pop
member.summary: Pops the latest copy of any stacking values off of their respective stacks, each UI element calls this at the end of it's rendering function EG: Blending color, clipping region, etc.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.onStack_Value_Change
member.summary: Fired anytime a value on our stack changes so we can update that data within whatever methods we are using to render.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Set_Matrix(CssUI.Matrix4)
member.summary: Sets the latest matrix value in the stack.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Upload_Matrix(CssUI.Matrix4)
member.summary: Uploads the current matrix value to whatever system is doing the rendering, be it DirectX, OpenGL, Vulkan, D3D, etc.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Set_Blending_Color(CssUI.Rendering.ReadOnlyColor)
member.summary: Sets the value of the latest tint color value in the blending stack. The 'tint' color refers to the color which the base color multiplies against itsself to obtain the final color value to be used when rendering verticies.
member.param: The tint color to multiply the base color by.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Set_Color(CssUI.Rendering.ReadOnlyColor)
member.summary: Sets the current color

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Upload_Color(CssUI.Rendering.ReadOnlyColor)
member.summary: Uploads the final, blended, color value to whatever system is doing the rendering, be it DirectX, OpenGL, Vulkan, D3D, etc.

member.name: M:CssUI.Rendering.RenderEngineBase.Finalize_Color
member.summary: Performs blending on the base color and then uploads it.

member.summary: Total sum duration of all frames for this texture

member.summary: Progresses the current frame number based on the number of seconds which have passed since it was last updated, given by deltaTime

member.summary: Rebuilds the timeline of all our frames.

member.name: T:CssUI.Rendering.GpuTextureFrame
member.summary: Single frame of a instance. Effectively just serves as a convenient pass-through between RGBA pixel-data and the UI's current implementation, which actually does all the handling/uploading of image data For example; an OpenGL rendering engine implementation would store a texture ID as an integer within a frame's instance, while some other engine might store something else which it uses to draw the image.

member.name: P:CssUI.Rendering.GpuTextureFrame.Handle
member.summary: Instance object given to us by the implementation, which it uses to actually handle the texture.

member.name: F:CssUI.Rendering.GpuTextureFrame.Duration
member.summary: Time (in seconds) this frame should be onscreen for

member.name: P:CssUI.Rendering.GpuTextureFrame.IsReady
member.summary: Returns whether this frame is ready for the instance to draw it, or if it still needs to be created.
